msDesc.head:
Letter from
Francis Beaufort Edgeworth
to Miss Lawrence, ,
Jany. January 9. 1838.

div.p:
I can not refrain from writing to thank you
& your sister, for having procur'd me the acquaintance
of Mr & Mrs Cayley, & of Lady Byron. On Saturday
last we din'd dined at Mr Cayley's & met some of the Eton
Tutors. & on Sunday, I met Mr De Morgan, one
of the Professors of the London University at
Ly. Lady Byrons
I had a very interesting conversation a day or two
before with her, on the subject of education & she was
so good as to say that she would recommend me
to her relative
Ld
Lord Byron as Tutor to his son, who is
now about to leave Westminster.

I mention these little particulars, as I am sure
it will give you pleasure to see that your introductions
"have done me Yeoman's service" - as Hamlet says.
I hope that you have celebrated Christmas & the New
Year as happily as you expected and that your child-niece
has been transplanted from out of your fostering
shelter, into her new situation so gently & happily
as not to break or bruise any of the slightest fibres
of the heart.

Have you seen a short letter of Dr. Channing's,
which has been reprinted at Liverpool, about
Catholicism? It seems to me that his love
of Liberty carries him too far, when he talks
of all Establishments melting away - and
of the advantages of plunging into a wild
unciviliz'd uncivilized state of society. Emotion, & spirit
& energetic Effort are certainly very sublime
things, & doubltess the highest qualities in men,
but still I think that Calmness, Rest & Regularity,
& what Imogene calls "one's journal course"
are never to be underrated with impunity - at least
by us common uninspir'd mortals.

It would be hopeless endless to enter by letter
on the great question of the Pure Reason versus
the Understanding, which you touch'd touched upon the day
I had the pleasure of spending with you at the Grange.
But I can't resist scribbling a little off the edge
of it, as it were - If all knowledge be deriv'd derived
from the senses, the knowledge of the immediate
objects of the senses must be the most certain
of all knowledge - as being the primary ground
of all the rest - Hence I must be more sure of
the existence of this bit of paper than of the existence
of God. Again how can we derive from the senses
the accuracy, & the eternal necessity of Mathematical
knowledge? or how could the senses supply us with
a knowledge of that without which themselves could
not exist, such as the notion of being, sameness,
difference, time space, &c. How could we possibly

take in such notions? How could we find out
sameness, & difference,
if we had not an innate
faculty by which to find it out? Such ideas
seem to me to be as necessarily presuppos'd presupposed
as innate organs of the mind in all perception,
as the ear & the eye are involv'd involved in all
seeing & hearing and one might I think as
well that by seeing I acquire an eye, or that
by thinking I acquire the faculties wherewith
I think, which are those very notions - By seeing
I learn that I have, & have had an eye - as
by thinking I learn that I have & have had
the innate ideas -

I have not yet avail'd availed myself of yr
your
to Mr Le Breton, as I have not yet been
able to afford myself a week's visit to the Town
But I look forward to doing so with much pleasure
during the ensuing month.

My wife begs to be very kindly remember'd remembered
to all your hospitable family - in which
wish I beg to join most heartily.
div.closer:
And I remain, Dear Madam
Yours very gratefully
Francis B Edgeworth
